Yes, certainly! One example of a building that was designed to withstand extreme weather conditions is the Taipei 101 tower in Taiwan. The tower is located in a region that is prone to typhoons and earthquakes, therefore the architects and structural engineers had to design a building that could resist these extreme weather events.

The building has a tuned mass damper, which is the world's largest and heaviest damper that helps to prevent the building from swaying during high winds and typhoons. The building's foundation is also designed to resist strong earthquakes by using a deep concrete mat foundation that is anchored to the bedrock beneath the tower.

The tower's exterior is clad with over 10,000 aluminium panels that are designed to withstand the strong winds and typhoons. Furthermore, the roof of the tower is made of steel and designed to withstand a 100-year wind event.

Overall, Taipei 101 tower is an excellent example of how architects and engineers design buildings to withstand extreme weather events, by incorporating various design features and materials that can handle these conditions.
